summary_points: 1. Lowe's Companies Inc. held its annual shareholder meeting on May 30, 2025, where shareholders voted on the election of directors, executive compensation, and the ratification of Deloitte & Touche LLP as the company's independent auditor.
2.  In the election of directors, significant numbers of votes were withheld for several candidates (ranging from 2 million to almost 10 million withheld votes), indicating some shareholder dissent.

3. The results of the advisory vote to approve named executive officer compensation for fiscal year 2024 showed 389,654,875 votes for, 25,675,654 votes against, and 1,382,551 abstentions, with 84,078,983 broker non-votes.

1. Kimberly-Clark Corporation (KMB) and Suzano S.A. (SUZ) announced a joint venture, effective mid-2026, combining substantially all of KMB's International Family Care and Professional (IFP) business, with Suzano owning 51% and KMB retaining 49%.

2. The transaction's implied enterprise value is approximately $3.4 billion, with an expected $1.7 billion upfront cash payment to KMB,  and  is predicted to be $0.30-0.40 dilutive to KMB's adjusted EPS in the first year following closing.

3.  KMB anticipates classifying the divested IFP businesses as discontinued operations starting with its second-quarter 2025 earnings report (expected early August 2025), and intends to return the net cash proceeds to shareholders via share repurchases.
1. WEC Energy Group announced a proposed private offering of $700,000,000 in convertible senior notes due 2028, with an option for initial purchasers to buy up to an additional $105,000,000.
2.  The company intends to use the net proceeds from the note offering for general corporate purposes, including repayment of short-term debt.
3. The offering's success is subject to market conditions, including interest rates and the trading price of WEC Energy Group's common stock;  there's no assurance the offering will be completed.

1. LyondellBasell Industries N.V. (LYB) announced plans to sell its olefins & polyolefins businesses in Carrington (UK), Tarragona (Spain), Münchsmünster (Germany), and Berre (France) to AEQ Amethyst B.V. for a base consideration of €167 million, subject to adjustments.

2. LYB expects to recognize a loss on sale of approximately $700 million to $900 million in connection with the transaction, primarily due to net working capital transfer, cash contributions, foreign currency translation adjustments, and separation costs.

3. The transaction is expected to close during the first half of 2026, subject to customary closing conditions including regulatory approvals and employee consultations; failure to close under certain circumstances could result in a €25 million termination payment for either party.

1. Procter & Gamble is restructuring, resulting in a projected loss of up to 7,000 non-manufacturing jobs (15% of the non-manufacturing workforce) and potentially more manufacturing job losses by the end of 2026.

2. The restructuring will cost between $1.0 and $1.6 billion, with $250 million to $400 million being non-cash expenses, and is expected to generate $700 million in annualized cost savings by the end of 2026.
3. The restructuring carries a risk of negatively impacting the achievement of the company's operational objectives.
1. As of May 11, 2025, Costco operated 905 warehouses globally, with 624 in the United States, 109 in Canada, and significant presences in Mexico, Japan, the United Kingdom, and other countries.
2.  Costco's short-term investments totaled $1,014 million as of May 11, 2025, a decrease of $225 million compared to September 1, 2024.
3.  A Japanese subsidiary repaid $103 million of its Guaranteed Senior Notes after the end of the third quarter 2025, on May 21, 2025.

1. Iron Mountain Inc. amended its 2014 Stock and Cash Incentive Plan on May 29, 2025, increasing the number of authorized shares from 20,750,000 to 25,350,000 and extending the plan's termination date to May 29, 2035.
2. At the May 29, 2025 Annual Meeting, stockholder votes on the named executive officer compensation plan were 211,858,914 for and 9,973,817 against.

3. The Board of Directors appointed members to the Audit, Compensation, Nominating and Governance, Finance, and Risk and Safety Committees, effective May 29, 2025, subject to re-election at the 2026 Annual Meeting.

1. At Booking Holdings Inc.'s June 3, 2025 annual meeting, a stockholder proposal to modify the company's special meeting threshold was not approved, receiving 13,464,542 votes for and 14,018,112 votes against.
2.  All board of director nominees were elected at the June 3, 2025 annual meeting, though votes against ranged from 100,462 to 1,364,317.
3. An advisory vote to approve 2024 executive compensation was approved with 24,288,898 votes for and 3,156,175 votes against.

1. On June 4, 2025, General Dynamics announced several executive promotions, including Danny Deep to Executive Vice President, Global Operations, and Jason Aiken to Executive Vice President, Combat Systems.
2.  The filing mentions a period of "growth and change" for the company, without providing specific numerical details on the extent of this growth.
3. No concrete future impacts or risks are detailed in this section of the filing.
1. GE HealthCare Technologies Inc. priced an underwritten offering of $650,000,000 in 4.800% Notes due January 15, 2031 and $850,000,000 in 5.500% Notes due June 15, 2035 on June 3, 2025.
2.  The notes are expected to be issued around June 9, 2025.
3. The offering was underwritten by Citigroup Global Markets Inc., J.P. Morgan Securities LLC, and Morgan Stanley & Co. LLC, and several other underwriters.

1. Diamondback Energy, Inc.'s subsidiary, Viper Energy, Inc., will acquire Sitio Royalties Corp. in an all-equity transaction valued at approximately $4.1 billion (including Sitio’s net debt of approximately $1.1 billion as of March 31, 2025).
2.  The transaction is expected to close subject to customary closing conditions.
3. Diamondback Stockholders, holding a majority of Viper's voting power, have approved the merger agreement and will not dispose of their shares for 90 days following closing, subject to exceptions.
